DOC.HEAD: European Community, East Germany Condemn Romania Crackdown
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The European Community said Wednesday it was cutting back economic relations with Romania to protest that country's crackdown on demonstrators, and East Germany and the World Council of Churches also issued condemnations. Here are some of the statements released: _ In Brussels, the EC Commission criticized the repression of anti-government protests as a ``most heartless demonstration of the abuse of human rights.'' EC Commissioner for External Relations Frans Andriessen said a 1980 agreement covering industrial goods ``should be frozen'' and planned visits and meetings will not be held. No new trade concession will be made ``pending any significant improvement in the situation.'' The Commission also offered to help some 25,000 Romanian refugees currently in Hungary. _ In East Germany, the Communist Party called on Romania's leadership to ``stop immediately all acts of violence against its own population'' and respect human rights. Another East German party leader, Lothar de Maiziere, chairman of the Christian Democratic Union, said he feared ``genocide'' in Romania and called for an emergency meeting of the U.N. Security Council on the situation, the state news agency ADN said. Young East Germans, meanwhile, staged a silent candlelight vigil in front of the Romanian embassy in East Berlin, and an unspecified number of students in Leipzig also protested publicly against the crackdown, ADN said. _ In Geneva, leaders of the World Council of Churches and affiliated organizations on Wednesday expressed shock at the crackdown and said it revealed the ``ruthlessness'' of Romania's leadership. ``We strongly condemn the use of violence in response to peoples' expression of their aspirations and of their longing for justice,'' said the statement issued at the Geneva WCC headquarters. The World Council comprises about 300 churches representing some 400 million Anglican, Protestant, Orthodox and other non-Roman Catholic Christians in more than 100 countries. _ The U.N.'s Special Rapporteur on Summary or Arbitrary Executions, Amos Wacko, sent an urgent cable from his Geneva office to Romania's Foreign Ministry about the reports that hundreds of people were killed at Timisoara last Sunday. Wacko ``appealed to the government of Romania to respect the right to life of the Romanian people in accordance in particular with the Convention on Civil and Political Rights,'' said an official at U.N. headquarters in New York. _ About 150 people outraged by the reported massacres protested outside Romania's embassy in Warsaw, Poland, on Wednesday, with some hurling stones and bottles of ink before being stopped by police. _ In Moscow, Moldavian delegates asked the Soviet Congress to appeal for ``reason and order'' in Romania to help their ethnic brethren there. _ In Israel, a firebomb was thrown at the Romanian Embassy in Tel Aviv, causing a small fire at a nearby construction site, Israel Television said. No injuries were reported.
